name: White Willow
climate: White Willow thrives in temperate climates with cool to cold winters and warm summers.
It prefers regions with a consistent level of moisture, often found near rivers or wetlands.
This plant is found predominantly in areas with sufficient rainfall throughout the year.
White Willow can tolerate a range of climatic conditions, from full sun to partial shade areas.
sunlight: White Willow grows best in areas with full sun exposure for most of the day.
It can withstand partial shade, but excessive shading may hinder its growth.
In its natural habitat, White Willow enjoys prolonged sunlight during the day.
Insufficient sunlight may lead to slower growth and a less robust appearance.
watering: White Willow requires consistently moist soil to thrive, especially during dry spells.
Watering should be regular, ensuring the soil does not completely dry out between sessions.
This plant benefits from a steady supply of water, mimicking its natural riverside habitats.
Avoid overwatering, but ensure that the plant receives enough to maintain soil moisture.
soil: White Willow prefers fertile soil that is rich in organic matter for optimal growth.
It thrives in loamy soils that provide good drainage while retaining enough moisture.
While adaptable, the plant does best in slightly acidic to neutral pH soil conditions.
Compacted or poor-grade soils should be improved with organic compost or amendments.
toxic: While generally safe, the bark of White Willow contains salicin, which can cause gastrointestinal upset if ingested in large amounts.
extra_care_tip: To prevent disease, avoid planting White Willow in areas with poor air circulation or overly wet conditions.
